prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

para.paratext: Review of decisions of the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation is at best difficult to obtain. In some cases, review is not permitted by any court. Although this extremely limited review at first appears different from that in federal district courts, it is similar to the effectively limited review of any pretrial case management order under the final order rule.

Orders denying a motion to transfer are not reviewable by any court.[1] Under the statute creating the Panel,[2] review of other decisions of the Panel is obtained only by extraordinary writ under the All Writs Statute.[3] Review of Panel decisions relating to transfer is truly extraordinary. Just look at the footnotes in this book if you doubt the paucity of reported circuit court decisions reviewing Panel decisions. Review by extraordinary writ really is the exclusive means of obtaining any form of appellate review of decisions of the Panel. Review by appeal is not available, and an appellate court reviewing such an appeal will deny it for lack of jurisdiction.[4]

The legislative scheme whereby appellate review is difficult to obtain was quite intentional. The statute provides for review by a single court of the transfer decision and its streamlined review process is consistent with its overall purpose of expediting the resolution of potentially crushing litigation. Judge Becker testified during the legislative hearings:

[If] the actions to be transferred by the panel were pending in several circuits, and the transfer orders were entered in the district courts of the several circuits, review proceedings might be filed in several Circuit Courts, of Appeals. This could easily result in conflicting decisions of the Courts of Appeals on the validity of the transfer orders. Much delay could ensue, which would prejudice the efficient disposition. of the litigation ordered to be transferred and defeat the purposes of the bill.

In order to avoid the confusion and delay which might otherwise result, paragraph (c) provides that the order of transfer, and such other orders as the panel may make, shall be entered in the office of the clerk of the transferee district and shall be effective when entered. Further, it is expressly provided in paragraph (e) that no proceedings for any review of an order of the panel may be entertained by any courts other than the United States Court of Appeals having jurisdiction over the transferee District Court and the Supreme Court of the United States. These provisions are very important because they avoid the possibility of multiple review proceedings and conflicting rulings which could frustrate and paralyze the operation of the temporary transfer procedures. At the same time paragraph (e) designates competent courts to entertain whatever review proceedings may be appropriate under the circumstances.[5]
All of the reported decisions reviewing actions of the Panel are cited in this chapter.

Mandamus is an appropriate means of effecting review for two reasons. It is traditionally the means of reviewing abuse of discretion by lower courts, and it is also a more expeditious means of obtaining review.[6]

In one case the Second Circuit Court of Appeals denied a writ of mandamus sought by a national bank objecting to transfer of a case away from its home district.[7] The Panel had rejected the national bank's arguments that the special venue provision in the National Bank Act[8] prevented transfer to another district both in the case ultimately brought before the Second Circuit[9] and in earlier cases.[10] The Second Circuit recognized that the purpose of transfer under 28 U.S.C.A. § 1407 was broader than considerations of venue and that the statute authorizes transfer to “any district” and not merely to a district where an action could have been brought initially.[11] Finding that the Panel's action was appropriate, the Second Circuit declined to issue a writ of mandamus. The decision reflects, however, an especially clear conflict between the special venue statute and the multidistrict venue statute that required appellate court interpretation. It is unlikely that the court of appeals would have given such exhaustive consideration to an application for a writ that was sought merely to determine if the Panel had made a prudent decision on transfer.

In a more recent case, the Third Circuit declined to issue a writ of mandamus to compel the Panel to dissolve the MDL proceedings and remand cases the petitioning plaintiffs viewed as ready for remand, but fully analyzed the issue under the criteria for the writ.[12] The court noted that the trial court had denied a motion for remand, that the Plaintiffs’ Management Committee opposed remand, and the Panel had declined the relief as well.[13] In FedEx Ground Package System, Inc. v. United States Panel on Multidistrict Litigation,[14] the court denied mandamus review of a Panel decision remanding cases following disposition on summary judgment on many the common issues, resulting in the claims in the remaining actions being returned to the districts where they were filed. This decision reflects the difficulty of obtaining review by mandamus, and the appellate court's strong deference to the Panel in on the highly discretionary decisions of the Panel on case management. The court also expressly pointed to the ability and discretion of the transferee judge in making his suggestion of remand to the Panel.[15]
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.
